title: Has anyone stood at the South Pole? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Lots of people, myself included. Interestingly there are two poles at the South Pole. The actual Geographic South Pole which is the point between the north and south pole which forms the axis the world spins one, and a ceremonial south pole which is 100 or so metres away. The ceremonial pole is a little bit closer to the station so this is the one people tend to get their hero shots at. The geographic south pole has a marker which is moved back to it’s correct position every year since the ice that sits atop the pole gradually slides down towards the ocean. These photos were taken in the middle of summer (January) when it was a mild -45c and yes it is damn cold still. You don’t want your skin uncovered for very long. Geographical South Pole (and it’s marker)   Ceremonial South Pole

Beginning a little more than a century ago starting with a group of Norwegians led by Amundsen. Now annually, several hundred people stand by the cerimonial Pole (I read Siple's book about how the reflective globe (an experiment left over) and the barber pole were made). I've been within 400 miles. I was told, should I go back with the USAP, they will wrangle a DV (Distinguished Visitor) seat for me. I said, that's nice but not essential. I go more to the Arctic these days. My friend Thom's photo at the Pole was with a satellite dish which he used to send the first email from Pole. My friend Roxanne got me a Ski South Pole tee shirt: 1/2 inch of powder, 2 miles of base. The USA has a base (Amundsen-Scott Station) as a way to contest the various pie slice claims of other countries. Another couple friends just came back from their civilian (January) visit there using a Russian transport with a Borck Air Twin Otter for the last leg. They took all the usual photos with the ceremonial Pole.

yes, heaps of people. There's a US base there: Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station I think there's a webcam but my Internet connection is too slow and expensive for me to go looking for it.  edit: I did a quick google and here's the webcam: ESRL Global Monitoring Division

Yes. At 14:12 hours on 14th December 1911 five Norwegians attained the South Geographical Pole. The actual first man to do so was as I recall a long distance skier called Bjaaland, he was followed by Hansen, Hassel, Wisting and at the rear was the leader - Roald Amundsen. Mathematically they were within about 1 nautical mile of the South Geographical Pole. All survived the trek and returned to Norway.

The Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen four team members arrived at the South pole on 14 December 1911. 5 weeks later the British Terra Nova Expedition led by Robert Falcon Scott arrived at the South Pole. Since then there has been approximately 30,000 exploreres who have been there, survived the trip and returned to regular civilization.

You can watch the web cam very near the South Pole. Google webcam scott amundsen station. Some times you see a person on the picture. Currently it is day time. sometimes it is rather foggy sometimes clear skies sunshine. Enjoy watching.
You know there’s a base there, right? Lots of people have stood at the South Pole. Here’s a few… :-)

There is a very large station (Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station - Wikipedia) at the very South Pole, with tens of people living there year round and innumerable temporary visitors since the opening in 1956.
